conclusion: To determine if the two objects have the same velocity at time \( t_1 \), we need to analyze their velocities using the given acceleration-time graph.

The graph shows the acceleration (\(a\)) of objects A and B as functions of time (\(t\)). Object A has a constant acceleration \(a_A\) starting from \(t=0\). Object B starts with zero acceleration and its acceleration increases linearly with time.

premise: Object A has a constant acceleration \(a_A\).
conclusion: The velocity \(v_A(t)\) of object A at any time \(t\) can be found by integrating the acceleration: \(v_A(t) = a_A \cdot t\).

premise: The velocity \(v_A(t)\) of object A at any time \(t\) is \(v_A(t) = a_A \cdot t\).
Object B's acceleration \(a_B(t)\) is a linear function of time. At \(t_2 = 2t_1\), the acceleration of B equals the constant acceleration of A.
conclusion: The slope \(k\) of the line is \(k = \frac{a_A}{2t_1}\).

premise: The slope \(k\) of the line for object B's acceleration is \(k = \frac{a_A}{2t_1}\).
conclusion: The acceleration of B as a function of time is \(a_B(t) = \frac{a_A}{2t_1} \cdot t\).

premise: The acceleration of B as a function of time is \(a_B(t) = \frac{a_A}{2t_1} \cdot t\).
conclusion: The velocity \(v_B(t)\) of object B at any time \(t\) can be found by integrating the acceleration: \(v_B(t) = \frac{a_A \cdot t^2}{4t_1}\).

premise: The velocity \(v_B(t)\) of object B at any time \(t\) is \(v_B(t) = \frac{a_A \cdot t^2}{4t_1}\).
Velocity of object A at \( t_1 \) is \(v_A(t_1) = a_A \cdot t_1\). Velocity of object B at \( t_1 \) is \(v_B(t_1) = \frac{a_A \cdot t_1}{4}\).
conclusion: Since \( v_A(t_1) \neq v_B(t_1) \), the two objects do not have the same velocity at time \( t_1 \).
